member.name: T:Remotion.Mixins.Globalization.MixedMultiLingualResources
member.summary: Provides a variant of that can be used to have mixins add resource identifiers to a target class. With this class, attributes are not only retrieved from the class and its base classes, but also from its mixins.
member.remarks:
The methods of this class do not have overloads taking object - getting and checking resources is always done via the type. The reason for this is as follows: If an instance was specified, its type would have to be used. Now, if the instance was not created by the , we would have to either:
Fall back to , because the "new-ed" object doesn't have any mixins, so the type-based resource lookup shouldn't use the mixins either; or
Be consistent with ExistsResource (obj.GetType()), ie. considering the mixins as well.
Both possibilities have a certain inconsistency, and none is perfect, so the class leaves it to the user to decide.

member.name: M:Remotion.Mixins.Context.DeclarativeConfigurationBuilder.BuildDefaultConfiguration
member.summary: Builds the default application configuration by analyzing all assemblies in the application bin directory and their (directly or indirectly) referenced assemblies for mixin configuration information. System assemblies are not scanned.
member.returns: A mixin configuration holding the default mixin configuration information for this application.
member.remarks:
This method uses the to discover the types to be used in the mixin configuration. In design mode, this will use the types returned by the designer, but in ordinary application scenarios, the following steps are performed:
Retrieve all types assemblies from the current AppDomain's bin directory.
Analyze each of them that is included by the for mixin configuration information.
Load the referenced assemblies of those assemblies if they aren't excluded by the .
If the loaded assemblies haven't already been analyzed, treat them according to steps 2-4.

member.name: T:Remotion.ExtensibleEnums.ExtensibleEnum`1
member.summary: Base class for extensible enums. Create extensible enums by deriving a class representing the enumeration from and define extension methods on to define the values of the enumeration. Each value is uniquely identified by the string passed to the constructor. Value comparisons act solely based on this identifier.
member.remarks: Instances of this class should be immutable, i.e. they should not change once initialized. This is due to their value semantics (a value retrieved from a cache should not be distinguishable from a value freshly created by an extension method call) and leads to inherent thread-safety.

member.name: M:Remotion.Utilities.EqualityUtility.GetRotatedHashCode``2(``0,``1)
member.summary: Gets the hash code of the individual arguments, XOR'd with bits rotated.

remarks.para: This method XOR's the hash codes of all individual arguments in order to create a compound hash code for the entire set of arguments. Between XOR's, the compound hash code is rotated by 11 bits in order to better distribute hash codes of types that aggregate their hash results toward the least-significant side of the result (small numbers, booleans).
Overloads with type arguments are identical to the object-array version, they only reduce the amount of boxing going on (better performance).

member.name: T:Remotion.Mixins.MixinConfiguration
member.summary: Constitutes a mixin configuration (ie. a set of classes associated with mixins) and manages the mixin configuration for the current thread (actually: ).

remarks.para: Instances of this class represent a single mixin configuration, ie. a set of classes associated with mixins. The class manages a thread-local (actually -local) single active configuration instance via its property and related methods; the active configuration can conveniently be replaced via the method.
also provides entry points for building new mixin configuration objects: , , and .
While the will usually be accessed only indirectly via or , and the BuildFrom... methods can be very useful to adjust a thread's mixin configuration at runtime.

The master mixin configuration - the default configuration in effect for a thread if not specifically replaced by another configuration - is obtained by analyzing the assemblies in the application's bin directory for attributes such as , , and . (For more information about the default configuration, see .) The master configuration can be accessed via and .

member.name: T:Remotion.Collections.Set`1
member.summary: Implements a set collection data type.
member.typeparam: The type of items to be stored by this collection.

remarks.para: A is an unordered collection of items, where each item added is held exactly once. When an item is added more than once (determined by the given or the default comparer ), the set will automatically ignore the second add operation.
The data type is internally based on a , so checking whether a set contains an item is very fast, but depends on the quality of the hashing algorithm used for .
This collection type does not support items being , is not automatically safe for multi-threading, and cannot be set to be read-only.

member.summary: Builds a string representing the signature of a given object. This is similar to the string returned by as it contains a textual representation of the event's type. It's different from , though, because it does not contain the event's name.

remarks.para: The signature string does currently not hold custom modifiers.

For simplicity, this class assumes that type or namespace names cannot contain the character "[". The 1:1 mapping of signature strings to event signatures is only guaranteed for events that adhere to these assumptions.

member.name: T:Remotion.Reflection.SignatureStringBuilding.PropertySignatureStringBuilder
member.summary: Builds a string representing the signature of a given object. This is similar to the string returned by as it contains a textual representation of the property's type and parameter types (without parameter names). It's different from , though, because it does not contain the property's name.

remarks.para: The signature string does currently not hold custom modifiers.

For simplicity, this class assumes that type or namespace names cannot contain the character "[". It encloses the property's index parameter list with "(" and ")" and separates the parameters by ",". It also assumes that the full name of a type (namespace, enclosing type (if any), and simple type name) is enough to identify a type - assembly information is not encoded. The 1:1 mapping of signature strings to property signatures is only guaranteed for properties that adhere to these assumptions.

member.name: T:Remotion.Mixins.Definitions.Building.OverriddenMemberFilter
member.summary: Takes a list of objects and removed those members that are overridden within that list, so that only the most derived members are returned. For members with more than one accessor (e.g. properties with a get and a set accessor), both overriding and overridden member are returned unless all accessors are overridden. This also applies in a chain of overrides - all members are returned that contain one accessor that is not overridden.

member.name: T:Remotion.Reflection.TypeDiscovery.AssemblyLoading.FilteringAssemblyLoader
member.summary: Loads assemblies and applies filters before returning them. Assemblies are loaded from a file path by first getting their corresponding and then loading the assembly with that name. This means that only assemblies from the assembly search path (application directory, dynamic directory, GAC) can be loaded, and that GAC assemblies are preferred. The advantage of this load mode is that assemblies are loaded exactly the same way as if loaded directly by .NET: they are always loaded into the correct context and references are resolved correctly.
member.remarks: The assemblies loaded by this class can be filtered by implementations of .

member.name: T:Remotion.Collections.SetBasedCacheKey`1
member.summary: Takes a set of objects and provides value-type semantics to the set, so that it can be used as a cache key.

remarks.para: This type implements by calculating the hash codes of all elements in the set wrapped by this collection and combining them in an (order-independent) way. Therefore, two instances of this type give the same hash codes if the elements wrapped by them give the same hash codes. It is not guaranteed that two instances of this type give different hash codes if the elements give different hash codes.
Similarly, is implemented by comparing the elements of the sets with each other. Two instances of this type compare equal if and only if they contain equal objects (without considering order).
For efficiency, the hash codes of instances of this type are cached. Changes to the objects wrapped by an instance do not influance the hash code and should therefore be avoided.
Note that, because this type is based on , equal elements are regarded as one. This is, a set (1, 1, 2, 2) is equivalent to a set (1, 2).

A is transformed into a new :

member.name: T:Remotion.Reflection.SignatureStringBuilding.MethodSignatureStringBuilder
member.summary: Builds a string representing the signature of a given object. This is similar to the string returned by as it contains a textual representation of the method's return type, parameter types (without parameter names), and generic parameter types. It's different from , though, because it does not contain the method's name or generic parameter names.

remarks.para: The signature string does currently not hold custom modifiers.

For simplicity, this class assumes that type or namespace names cannot contain the character "[". It encloses the parameter list with "(" and ")" and separates the parameters by ",". It also assumes that the full name of a type (namespace, enclosing type (if any), and simple type name) is enough to identify a type - assembly information is not encoded. The 1:1 mapping of signature strings to method signatures is only guaranteed for methods that adhere to these assumptions.
This class does not support closed generic methods, only generic method definitions are supported.

member.name: T:Remotion.Reflection.MemberSignatureEqualityComparer

member.name: M:Remotion.Diagnostics.ToText.ToTextProvider.RegisterDefaultToTextProviderHandlers
member.summary:
Registers the default handlers for the conversion of arbitray objects into human readable text form. Handlers form a fallback cascade starting with registered external object-to-text-conversion-handlers.
The handlers are registered in the following order of precedence:
Handler for specific object type registered (see ).
Implements (i.e. object supplies method).
Is a string or character (see and respectively).
Implements IFormattable ("is a primitive"); Primitives (e.g. floating point numbers) are alway output formatted locale agnostic.
Is a (rectangular) array (rectangular arrays have to be treated seperately since the IEnumerable handler would treat them as one-dimensional).
Implements IEnumerable.
Handler for a specific interface which the object implements is registered (see e.g. ).
Handler for a base type of the specific object type registered (see ).
Log instance members through reflection.
Use object's method.

member.name: T:Remotion.Reflection.TypeDiscovery.AssemblyLoading.RegexAssemblyLoaderFilter
member.summary: Filters the assemblies loaded during type discovery by name, excluding those whose names match a given regular expression. Whether to match the simple name or the full name can be specified.

member.name: T:Remotion.Reflection.TypeDiscovery.AssemblyLoading.IAssemblyLoaderFilter
member.summary: Provides an interface for filtering the assemblies loaded by the .
member.remarks: The filtering interface provides a two-step model: first, the checks whether the assembly name fits the criteria of the filter implementation, then, it checks whether the assembly itself fits the criteria. If the locates an assembly on disk, it will only load it if the assembly's name passes the first step. After loading, the second step can still reject the assembly based on more detailed investigation.

IsInnermostLoop, IsOutermostLoop can be queried to treat the innermost and outermost loop differently, if so required.

member.summary: Provides methods for declaring command line syntax and providing values.

member.name: M:Remotion.Text.CommandLine.CommandLineParser.SplitCommandLine(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Splits a command line string into an array of command line arguments, separated by spaces.
member.param: The command line (as available from .)
member.returns: An array of command line arguments.
member.remarks:
The following rules apply:
Use spaces to separate arguments.
Embed arguments within double quotation marks to treat them as a single argument even if they contain spaces.
Within double quotation marks, use two double quotation marks if you need one double quotation mark in the argument.
This resembles the logic that is applied to the arguments of the C# Main method. However, the parameters passed to the Main method are parsed a little bit differently in special situations, according to an unknown and undocumented algorithm.
member.param: If , the first argument (which is usually the file name of the program) is included, otherwise only the arguments after the first one are included.

member.summary: This method reads a command line and initializes the arguments contained in .
member.param: The string that contains the command line arguments. See for information on how command lines are parsed.
If , the first argument (which is usually the file name of the program) is included, otherwise only the arguments after the first one are included.
member.exception: The value of a parameter cannot be interpreted.
The command line contains a named argument that is not defined.
The command line contains too many unnamed arguments.
A non-optional command line argument is not contained in the command line.

member.name: T:Remotion.Utilities.Assertion
member.summary: Provides methods that throw an if an assertion fails.

remarks.para: This class contains methods that are conditional to the DEBUG and TRACE attributes ( and ).

Note that assertion expressions passed to these methods are not evaluated (read: executed) if the respective symbol are not defined during compilation, nor are the methods called. This increases performance for production builds, but make sure that your assertion expressions do not cause any side effects! See or and the for more information about conditional compilation.
Assertions are no replacement for checking input parameters of public methods (see ).

member.name: T:Remotion.Utilities.WorkContext
member.summary: Provides context information for error messages.

remarks.para:
Exceptions contain a stack trace of the time the exception was thrown, so it is easy to identify the code that caused the exception. However, there is no information as to which data this code was processing, or which iteration of a certain loop caused a problem. For programs that process large amount of data and fail for specific data, it can be tedious to find the state or data that caused an error.
WorkContexts provide an easy way to specify which data is currently being processed. In an exception handling block, the current context stack can be used to get diagnostic information about the state of the application when the exception occured.

member.summary: Leaves the context. .

member.name: M:Remotion.Utilities.WorkContext.Leave
member.summary: Leaves the context.

remarks.para: The context is left, but remains on the stack until the method is called, or a new context is entered. Therefore, the left context is still available for inspection (e.g. in an exception handling block).
A context that is left, but not done, is prefixed with a question mark in the context stack output. Use this information if you are not sure whether all calls to were coded correctly.
In C# it is generally recommended to use a using statement rather than calling Leave explicitly.

member.name: M:Remotion.Utilities.WorkContext.Done
member.summary: Marks the context as done.

remarks.para:
Call this method if the work within a context has been processed successfully (i.e., no uncaught exception has been raised).
For C# users, it is recommended to call this method at the end of the using block that contains the context.

member.name: T:Remotion.Reflection.TypeDiscovery.AssemblyLoading.ApplicationAssemblyLoaderFilter
member.summary: Filters the assemblies loaded during type discovery by name, excluding those whose names resemble system assemblies or assemblies generated by the mixin engine. In addition, assemblies that have the defined are also excluded. Note that assemblies have to be loaded in memory in order to check whether the attribute is present. This will also lock the assembly files.
member.remarks:
The name-based filtering by default excludes the following assembly name patterns:
mscorlib
System
System\..*
Microsoft\..*
Remotion\..*\.Generated\..*
This list might change in the future, and it can be extended via .

member.summary: Provides a common utility class for classes building strings representing the signature of a given object.

remarks.para: For simplicity, this class assumes that type or namespace names cannot contain the character "[". It also assumes that the full name of a type (namespace, enclosing type (if any), and simple type name) is enough to identify a type - assembly information is not encoded. The 1:1 mapping of signature strings to member signatures is only guaranteed for members that adhere to these assumptions.

member.name: T:Remotion.Mixins.CodeGeneration.ConcreteTypeBuilder
member.summary: Provides a way to build concrete types for target and mixin classes in mixin configurations and maintains a cache for built types.

remarks.para: You can use different instances of by setting them as the property via . Each of these will have its own instance of as its , and each scope will have its own dynamic assembly for code generation. However, each scope's assembly will have the same default name.

Having different assemblies with the same names loaded into one AppDomain can lead to sporadic TypeLoadExceptions in reflective scenarios. To avoid running into such errors, set the and properties of the to unique names for each instance you use.

member.param: A delegate accessing the scope while access to it is locked.
member.remarks: This methods locks the scope while executing . This ensures that no other method of modifies the scope while it is being accessed.

member.name: M:Remotion.Mixins.CodeGeneration.ConcreteTypeBuilder.SaveAndResetDynamicScope
member.summary: Saves the dynamic of this builder to disk and resets it, so that the builder can continue to generate types. Use the Scope's properties via to configure the name and paths of the modules being saved.
member.returns: An array containing the paths of the assembly files saved.

remarks.para: This is similar to directly calling Scope.SaveAssemblies, but in addition resets the to a new instance of . That way, the builder can continue to generate types even when the dynamic assemblies have been saved. Note that each time this method is called, only the types generated since the last save operation are persisted. Also, if the scope isn't reconfigured to save at different paths, previously saved assemblies might be overwritten.

Having different assemblies with the same names loaded into one AppDomain can lead to sporadic TypeLoadExceptions in reflective scenarios. To avoid running into such errors, set the and properties of the to new, unique names after calling this method.

member.name: M:Remotion.Mixins.CodeGeneration.ConcreteTypeBuilder.BeginDeserialization(System.Func{System.Type,System.Type},System.Runtime.Serialization.SerializationInfo,System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContext)
member.summary: Begins deserialization of a mixed object.
member.param: A transformation object that is given a chance to modify the deserialized type before it is instantiated.
The object provided by the .NET serialization infrastructure.
The object provided by the .NET serialization infrastructure.
member.returns: An object containing a partially deserialized mixed object. Be sure to call from an implementation of to finish the deserialization process.
member.exception: One or more of the parameters passed to this method are .
The serialization data does not hold the expected values.

remarks.para: This method is useful when the mixin engine is combined with other code generation mechanisms. In such a case, the default implementation provided by the mixin code generation can be extended by a custom object by calling this method. This method instantiates the real object to be returned by the deserialization process, but the caller specifies a delegate that gets the chance to modify the type of object before it is instantiated. The parameter passed to is the type deducted from the deserialized mixin configuration-
This method expects that the deserialized data is from a mixed object, calling it for an unmixed object will yield an exception.

member.name: M:Remotion.Mixins.CodeGeneration.ConcreteTypeBuilder.FinishDeserialization(System.Runtime.Serialization.IObjectReference)
member.summary: Finishes a deserialization process started by .
member.param: The object returned from .

remarks.exception: The parameter does not hold an object returned by the method.
remarks.para: Call this method to complete deserialization of a mixed object when the .NET serialization infrastructure has finished its work, e.g. from an implementation of . After this method, the real object contained in can safely be used.
If the given instance is not an instance of a mixed type, this method does nothing.
